docs.snippet: Leaders in Serbia were still promising to comply but took no concrete steps today to meet an American-imposed deadline of Monday morning local time for greater cooperation with the tribunal trying suspects for war crimes.    The Yugoslav foreign m...
docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders in Serbia were still promising to comply but took no concrete steps today to meet an American-imposed deadline of Monday morning local time for greater cooperation with the tribunal trying suspects for war crimes. The Yugoslav foreign minister, Goran Svilanovic, was quoted tonight on Serbian television as saying that he did not expect any immediate extraditions.
docs.abstract: Serbian leaders still promise to comply but take no concrete steps to meet American-imposed deadline of April 1 for greater cooperation with UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague; Foreign Minister Goran Svilanovic says there will not be any immediate extraditions of war crimes suspects; similar sentiments are echoed by Justice Minister Vladan Batic, who issues arrest warrants for four close aides of former President Slobodan Milosevic, currently being tried in Hague; four were indicted along with Milosevic for war crimes during war in Kosovo in 1999; US Congress has threatened to freeze $120 in badly needed financial assistance unless Yugoslavia shows greater cooperation by midnight March 31 (M)

headline.main: Serbia Delays Extradition Of War Crimes Suspects

docs.snippet: IF termites have started eating your house, chances are it will be years before you notice. Experts at chewing from the inside out, termites can carve their tunnels within a paper's width of the outside of a piece of wood, remaining out of sight. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IF termites have started eating your house, chances are it will be years before you notice. Experts at chewing from the inside out, termites can carve their tunnels within a paper's width of the outside of a piece of wood, remaining out of sight. Even when they accidentally break through, they quickly patch the hole with ''termite mud'' -- a mixture of dirt, excrement and chewed wood. A little pile of dirt on the floor or a mud stain on a wall are often the earliest signs that termites have moved in. By the time termites make themselves visible -- a swarm of ''winged reproductives'' seeking to establish new colonies -- they have been munching for several years. Dr. Nan-Yao Su, an entomology professor at the University of Florida, estimates that Americans spend more than $2 billion annually to eradicate termites. ''That does not account for people paying the carpenter to repair their house,'' Dr. Su said. Add in repairs, and the costs might exceed $10 billion a year, he said.
docs.abstract: Termite-fighting strategies have changed over time and scientists are working to develop more sophisticted methods of protecting homes; drawing (Special Section, Nesting) (M)

headline.main: At War With an Invisible Army

docs.snippet: With tens of millions of dollars in American financial aid frozen, the Yugoslav government pledged today to cooperate ''fully'' with the international war crimes tribunal.    ''This means allowing access to archives in a way that does not harm nat...
docs.lead_paragraph: With tens of millions of dollars in American financial aid frozen, the Yugoslav government pledged today to cooperate ''fully'' with the international war crimes tribunal. ''This means allowing access to archives in a way that does not harm national dignity and the arrest and transfer to The Hague of those charged with war crimes,'' the Yugoslav foreign minister, Goran Svilanovic, told reporters in the Serbian capital, Belgrade, after a special session of the Yugoslav cabinet.
docs.abstract: Yugoslav Government pledges to cooperate fully with international war crimes tribunal, acting after US freezes $40 million in aid; Foreign Min Goran Svilanovic says access will be allowed to archives in way that does not harm national dignity; will allow arrest and transfer to Hague of those charged as war criminals (S)

headline.main: Yugoslavia to Cooperate With War Tribunal

docs.snippet: For weeks, Satvika Prabhu, 15, and her friends in the ninth grade have been agog. They cannot seem to stop talking about each new blow and counterblow in an all-out marketing war between Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, fought out on television with ads,...
docs.lead_paragraph: For weeks, Satvika Prabhu, 15, and her friends in the ninth grade have been agog. They cannot seem to stop talking about each new blow and counterblow in an all-out marketing war between Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, fought out on television with ads, counterads and counter-counterads as the weather starts to soar into summer heat. New salvos appear almost daily, leaving Satvika and millions of Indians like her, mainstays of the $1.2 billion soft drink market in India, engrossed and dying for more.
docs.abstract: Article on advertising and marketing war in soft drink industry in India to attract young consumers; Coca-Cola Co and PepsiCo Inc are leading campaign to gain market share in India's $1.2 billion soft drink market (M)

headline.main: Sassy Ads Enliven Soda War In India

docs.snippet: Thursday night's concert at the Ethical Culture Society by the adventurous Eos Orchestra, the first of its seventh season, provided an opportunity to consider works in which five American composers, including the ensemble's composer in residence, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Thursday night's concert at the Ethical Culture Society by the adventurous Eos Orchestra, the first of its seventh season, provided an opportunity to consider works in which five American composers, including the ensemble's composer in residence, Jake Heggie, tried to assimilate existing musical styles in fresh and authentic ways. The program, conducted by the ensemble's artistic director, Jonathan Sheffer, opened with the Andante for Strings (1931) by Ruth Crawford Seeger. In this gripping five-minute work, subdued, gnarly two-note gestures are repeated, then prolonged into ruminative lines and stacked atop one another to create an astringent, quietly powerful mass of counterpoint.
docs.abstract: Anthony Tommasini reviews Eos Orchestra concert, conducted by Jonathan Sheffer and featuring soprano Pamela Armstrong; photo (M)

headline.main: From Civil War Songs To Childhood Memories

headline.main: What Did You Do in the War?

docs.snippet: First her leftist husband disappeared and then all four of her daughters and two sons-in-law. The ''dirty war'' that took them ended long ago, but Elsa Oesterheld has never stopped feeling that pain.    ''The disappearance of a person leaves those...
docs.lead_paragraph: First her leftist husband disappeared and then all four of her daughters and two sons-in-law. The ''dirty war'' that took them ended long ago, but Elsa Oesterheld has never stopped feeling that pain. ''The disappearance of a person leaves those who loved him with a sensation of permanent and irreversible anguish,'' she said. ''Even though you have the conviction that they are dead, they're not really dead to you because you have no proof. To this day, I do not have any death certificates, and it all leaves me wondering: why did they kill them and not me?''
docs.abstract: Families of 30,000 Argentines who disappeared during country's 'dirty war' of 1970's are bearing uniquely painful burden as nation suffers through it's worst economic crisis ever; government, after admitting responsibility for deaths and promising to pay sizeable indemnity, has broken its word by freezing bank accounts and suspending payments on its debts; photos (M)

docs.snippet: CARLA DEL PONTE does not like to talk about herself because her business is others. Tracking down and prosecuting others.    On Tuesday, she will take her place in court as the trial of her main adversary, Slobodan Milosevic, opens. It will be Eur...
docs.lead_paragraph: CARLA DEL PONTE does not like to talk about herself because her business is others. Tracking down and prosecuting others. On Tuesday, she will take her place in court as the trial of her main adversary, Slobodan Milosevic, opens. It will be Europe's most important war-crimes trial in half a century. Beyond that, she is responsible for a staggering caseload of war crimes from the Balkans and the Rwandan genocide of 1994.
docs.abstract: Profile of Carla del Ponte, chief prosecutor for UN tribunals for war crimes in former Yugoslavia and Rwanda; photo; Switzerland's most prominent woman, who campaigned to cut through Swiss bank secrecy and tracked down accounts of dictators and criminals, is also familiar with death threats; latest are coming from Balkans as UN prepares to try former Serb leader Slobodan Milosevic (M)

headline.main: On War Criminals' Trail, an Unflagging Hunter

docs.snippet: The letters shown here, sent to and from the front lines, offer an intimate record of our country at war. It used to be that war letters themselves -- like the bloodstained missives of Union and Confederate soldiers -- revealed something of the fu...
docs.lead_paragraph: The letters shown here, sent to and from the front lines, offer an intimate record of our country at war. It used to be that war letters themselves -- like the bloodstained missives of Union and Confederate soldiers -- revealed something of the fury of battle, but as e-mail replaces the handwritten word, our correspondence has become less formal and more detached. This selection of letters from the 19th century to the present is a vivid reminder of the anxieties of those who serve and the sacrifices that war demands. Civil War, Feb. 14, 1863 In this Valentine's Day missive, a Confederate soldier's wife implored her husband, ''O do try and take care of your self so that you will live to come home.'' After the fighting at Chancellorsville, a Union soldier took this bloodstained letter from the dead husband and kept it as a souvenir, not uncommon at the time.
docs.abstract: Sampling of letters from 19th century to present sent home by American soldiers at war; photos (S)

headline.main: America at War in Five Letters
headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 1-27-02: DOCUMENT

docs.snippet: India has moved short-range ballistic missiles to the border with Pakistan, defense officials said today, as part of a military buildup that some Western diplomats characterized as the largest since the two rivals fought their last war 30 years ag...
docs.lead_paragraph: India has moved short-range ballistic missiles to the border with Pakistan, defense officials said today, as part of a military buildup that some Western diplomats characterized as the largest since the two rivals fought their last war 30 years ago. Military analysts said the ''Prithvi'' missiles, which have a range up to 150 miles, are capable of carrying nuclear warheads. But these analysts said it was highly unlikely that the missiles are carrying them now, and India has a policy of no first use of nuclear weapons.
docs.abstract: India moves short-range ballistic missiles to Pakistan border as part of major military buildup; Min George Fernandes says large-scale mobilization will be finished in two or three days, leaving India 'ready for any eventuality;' India closes its airspace to Pakistan, takes other steps to punish Pakistan for failing to shut down Jaish-e-Muhammad and Lashkar-e-Taiba, groups it blames for attack on Indian Parliament; Pakistan responds with matching punitive steps; photos (M)

headline.main: India and Pakistan Add to War Footing
